maps.text: Map of Asia highlighting an approximate region that would have been governed by the Tang Dynasty (唐代) (Netchev, S., ; Benn, C. D., ; Lin, Z., & Xie, Y., , pp. 7). The area has been marked approximately to provide the reader with a clear visualization.

common.text:
### Tang Dynasty (唐代)

#### Golden Years

According to various researchers, the period of the Tang Dynasty (唐代) could be considered the *"golden years of Chinese culture," a title justified by the intense production of poetry, art, and music. Additionally, the implementation of a legal system that came into effect in the year <htdate0> and remained until <htdate1> (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

#### Climate Problem

The Tang Dynasty (唐代) period is also known for being marked by intense climatic events, such as strong winter monsoons, which, among their consequences, may have contributed to the end of the Tang Dynasty (唐代) (<htcite2>).

Reflection 1: And Now

You are a ruler facing great difficulties due to climate changes. As a result, your population is suffering intensely and could revolt at any moment.

What actions would you take in these difficult times to help your people and ensure your political survival?

The scenario between <htdate0> and <htdate1> was not the best due to natural effects. As a consequence, the Tang Dynasty (唐代) even faced a situation where 70% to 80% of the population was forced to flee or resort to banditry. The chaotic situation reached the point of a major rebellion in the year <htdate2>, known as the An‑Shi Rebellion (<htcite0>).

Violent repression in situations like those described could generate even more violence. Faced with this scenario, the Tang Dynasty (唐代) apparently chose a path that sought pacification, encouraging the population to venerate their local gods. This intensified devotion to local deities, leading to the performance of various rituals and sacrifices that, as poems from the time demonstrate, *"saved them from drought by sending rains"* (<htcite1>).

It should be emphasized that, in addition to religious rituals, during this same period, thanks to this devotion to local gods (<htcite2>):

• "the holding of ritual prayers for the local gods enabled officials to rapidly amass considerable financial and human resources. The resources were subsequently allocated to the maintenance of water conservancy projects, such as Wubei Yan "
And, when water is conserved, it becomes possible to maintain the water cycle (**Figure 2**).
Figure 4: Water Cycle. Public domain image from the U.S. Geological Survey (Water Cycle, , U.S. Geological Survey).

Reflection 2: In China (Zhongguo 中國) Too

Have you ever read a book in which God (or Gods) punishes humanity until they return to revering Him?

Could this be something common among us, human beings?

Have you heard of someone manipulating people through religion or the figure of a God?

The work we have just superficially studied in this text presents an in-depth analysis of historical events. Does it somehow prove the existence or non-existence of God or Gods?

#### Trade

Another notable fact of the Tang Dynasty (唐代) is that coins minted during the Kaiyuan reign have been found in East Africa. Although it is not possible to ensure that these coins reached the continent through direct trade with China (Zhongguo 中國)—since Chinese coins were also used in other regions of East Asia—the fact that they were found in Africa indicates the possible use of these coins in commercial exchanges that, if they did not occur during the Tang Dynasty (唐代) period, happened later (<htcite0>).

#### Names

When studying ancient Chinese documents, it is possible to observe that emperors are referenced in different ways. At birth, just like us today, they have a given name and a surname, but the surname always appears first in writing.

In addition to their name, they can also be found mentioned by their “temple names” (廟號), which are names attributed to them after their death, written on ancestral tablets in a great temple. The way these posthumous names are applied is not uniform over time, but in the Tang dynasty (唐代), as there were many emperors from the same dynasty, the convention of using generic terms like “zong” was adopted (<htcite0>).

In this text, we follow the tradition of the Qin dynasty (秦代) of using the person's name out of respect for ancestors (<htcite1>). Accordingly, we will use the posthumous temple names listed by Sun Jianqiang (<htcite2>).

history.text:
The Tang Dynasty (唐代) began immediately after the fall of the Sui Dynasty (隋代), which ruled China (Zhongguo 中國) between <htdate0> and <htdate1> (<htcite0>). The rise of this dynasty, which lasted nearly 300 years (<htdate2>-<htdate3>), ushered in a new golden age in China (Zhongguo 中國) (<htcite2>; <htcite3>).

Although we are speaking of a Chinese dynasty, there is genetic evidence that helps in understanding the origin of the Tang (唐) which needs to be clarified. Studies of individuals from the Tang Dynasty (唐代) buried in the Fudamen (傅大门) cemetery in Shandong province indicate that they belonged to the Hu people (胡人) ethnic minorities living in northwest China (Zhongguo 中國), Central Asia, and western Eurasia. This suggests there was a process of sinicization of the Hu people (胡人)—a process by which non-Han cultures absorb elements of Han culture—through intermarriage (<htcite4>).

These intermarriages were, in a way, expected, as during the Sui (隋) and Tang (唐) dynasties, there was significant development of the Silk Road. Consequently, there was a continuous process of population mixing, with the ancestors of the Tang Dynasty (唐代) possibly being descendants of Sogdians from the Bukhara (安国) region in present-day Uzbekistan (<htcite5>).

source.text: Wang, R., Liu, W., Wu, Y. et al.
Wang, R., Liu, W., Wu, Y. et al.

history.text:
Following the death of Yang Guang, marking the end of the Sui Dynasty (隋代), it was observed that the main regions came to be ruled by *"strongmen, bandits, or elites from earlier dynasties further south"* (<htcite0>).

It is in this scenario that the Tang Dynasty (太原), emerged. It began in the Taiyuan (太原) region, a frontier stronghold whose function was defense against attacks by the Turks. Precisely the contact with these foreign peoples allowed the Tang Dynasty to emerge within a political sphere centered on a Turkic confederation (<htcite1>).

During his reign, Li Yuan had to face various rivals and rebels, consolidating complete control of the northern and southern regions of China (Zhongguo 中國) around <htdate0> (<htcite2>).

Li Yuan (李淵) adopted the land distribution and taxation system of the Sui Dynasty (隋代). Among his most notable achievements was the introduction of copper coins (**Figure 3**), which continued to be used in later dynasties (<htcite3>; <htcite4>).
Figure 3: Tang Dynasty coin from the year , at the British Museum. © Trustees of the British Museum (The British Museum ).
In addition to his personal name, Li Yuan (李淵) is also known by his posthumous name Gaozu (高祖) (<htcite0>).
In the analyzed works, there is no mention of marriages. Nor can it be ruled out that Li Yuan (李淵) had more than one relationship.
Li Jiancheng (李建成), eldest son of Li Yuan (李淵) (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).
Li Shimin (李世民) was the second emperor of the dynasty, assuming the throne after his father's death.  According to Wong Weng Pok, he was the emperor's second son (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).
Li Yuanji (李元吉), hijo menor de Li Yuan (李淵) (<htcite0>).

Although not the firstborn son, he managed to thwart some plans by his brother Li Jiancheng (李建成) to seize power from their father, Li Yuan (李淵). After foiling a coup attempt by his brother, he himself ended up taking over his father's rule (<htcite0>).

The success of Li Shimin's (李世民) rise to power can be credited to his qualities as a military leader. As highlighted by W. P. Wong, Li Shimin (李世民) maintained a good personal relationship with his military personnel, regardless of whether they were of Chinese origin or not (<htcite1>). Also notable regarding his good relationships is his connection with Turkish nobles. According to Chen Yinke (陳寅恪), thanks to a blood oath with a Turkish noble, Li Shimin (李世民) was accepted by the Turks as one of their own (<htcite2>).

Li Shimin (李世民) died of dysentery in the year <htdate0>. His legacy can be observed in the fact that various subsequent emperors followed his examples (<htcite3>).

Known as Taizong (太宗), Li Shimin (李世民) received other titles after his death, with the last one adopted being *"The Great Civil and Martial, Vast and Bright, Filially Extensive Emperor"* (Wenwu Dasheng Daguangxiao Huangdi 文武大聖大廣孝皇帝) (<htcite4>; <htcite5>).
In the analyzed works, there is no mention of marriages. Nor can it be ruled out that Li Shimin (李世民) had more than one relationship.
Information mentioned in the studied sources (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

During his 34-year reign (<htdate0> - <htdate1>), he expanded the domains of the Tang dynasty (唐代) to the Korean peninsula, making that region a vassal state in <htdate2> (<htcite0>).

Despite the lengthy reign, the emperor was not the most prominent figure of his rule. In some works, the monarch is portrayed as a weak character, with effective governance exercised by Wu Zetian (武則天), a former concubine of his father who became his consort (<htcite0>; <htcite1>; <htcite2>).

Li Zhi (李治) is also known by his name Gaozong (高宗), his temple name (<htcite3>).
Empress of noble origin, deposed by Wu Zetian (武則天) (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).
First concubine (<htcite0>).
According to the sources studied (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).
Name not provided in the *World History Encyclopedia* (<htcite0>).
Name not provided in the *World History Encyclopedia* (<htcite0>).
Name not provided in the *World History Encyclopedia* (<htcite0>).
According to information from the *World History Encyclopedia* (<htcite0>).
According to information from the *World History Encyclopedia* (<htcite0>).
According to *Britannica Encyclopedia* (<htcite0>).
According to J. W. Jay (<htcite0>).

Li Xian (李顯), also known by his name Zhongzong (中宗), ruled in two distinct periods. The first lasted less than a month, between <htdate0> and <htdate1>, being deposed by his mother upon realizing that his wife, Empress Wei (韋), exercised strong influence, contrary to her plans. This led to Li Xian (李顯) being removed from the throne and exiled by his own mother, Wu Zetian (武則天) (<htcite0>; <htcite1>; <htcite2>).

Upon returning from exile, he reassumed the throne for a second reign, between <htdate2> and <htdate3>. Shortly after his return, he transferred the capital from Luoyang to Chang'an (<htcite3>).

His government was not long — and, according to some accounts, not fully effective either. During this short period, power was largely exercised by Empress Wei (韋), who would also have been responsible for his death, by poisoning him. Subsequently, she placed her son, Li Chongmao (李重茂), on the throne, acting as regent (<htcite4>; <htcite5>; <htcite6>).
According to different sources (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).
According to different sources (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

After the death of his father, Li Chongmao (李重茂) was placed on the throne on <htdate0>, having his mother, Empress Wei (韋), as regent. His reign was even briefer, as a revolt led by his uncle Li Dan (李旦) and Princess Taiping (太平) forced him to abdicate in favor of Li Dan (李旦) (<htcite0>).

After his death, he was recognized by the posthumous name Shangdi (殤帝) (<htcite1>).

Like his brother, Li Xian (李顯), he ruled for two periods, both directly related to him. After his brother was deposed for the first time, his mother, Wu Zetian (武則天), placed him on the throne under her regency on <htdate0>. However, Li Dan (李旦) also came to disappoint his mother, being deposed by her on <htdate1>, so that she could finally declare herself empress (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

After an act coordinated by his son, Li Longji (李隆基) with his sister, Princess Taiping (太平), Li Xian (李顯) returned to government on <htdate2> (<htcite2>; <htcite3>). However, it cannot be said that the return to government was serene or that the three acted in peace to secure the family's kingdom. Princess Taiping (太平) and her brother again came into conflict, a fact that led him to pass the throne to his son, who reluctantly assumed it on <htdate3> (<htcite4>).

After transferring control of the kingdom to his son, Li Dan (李旦), also known by his name Ruizong (睿宗), assumed the position of Emperor Emeritus (Taishanghuang (太上皇)) (<htcite5>).
The fact that the new emperor was his son confirms the existence of this person (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).
According to researched sources (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

One of the main figures in his father's seizure of power in the year <htdate0>, he eventually assumed governance shortly after, in <htdate1>, when the family was still struggling through the turbulent succession following his grandmother, Empress Wu Zetian (武則天). Governance only stabilized after the authorization for his aunt Taiping (太平) to take her own life (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

His years of rule were marked by relative stability and a balance of power that included, even, Buddhist and Daoist religious leaderships (<htcite2>; <htcite3>; <htcite4>). As a consequence of this stability, the period of Li Longji's (李隆基) rule was characterized by social and cultural progress, in addition to an economic boom that led the interval from <htdate2> to <htdate3> to be known as the Kaiyuan Era (<htcite5>; <htcite6>; <htcite7>).

One of the possible consequences observed due to the advancements of his reign was the direct association of the emperor with figures from popular beliefs, such as Zhong Kui (鍾馗) (**Figure 4**), responsible for capturing and eliminating wandering demons and subsequently consolidated as a figure linked to exorcism practices (<htcite8>).
Figure 4: Vertical scroll painting. Emperor Xuanzong (玄宗) (Genso), Zhong Kui (Shoki) and another expelling demons, at the British Museum. © Trustees of the British Museum (The British Museum ).

In addition to the aforementioned advancements, Li Longji (李隆基), also known by his name Xuanzong (玄宗), managed to establish a great army of approximately 600,000 men, which aided in maintaining the stability of the Silk Road and in the dissemination of knowledge from China (Zhongguo 中國) to the West (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

The end of Li Longji's (李隆基) rule also marks the end of an era of progress that made China (Zhongguo 中國) one of the most prosperous nations in the world (<htcite2>). In his later years, starting in <htdate0>, the An Lushan (安祿山) Rebellion erupted, an event that marked the beginning of a new stage in the history of China (Zhongguo 中國). Although the figure in question passed away in <htdate1> and barely lived to see the rebellion unfold, it had significant consequences, such as the fragmentation of the kingdom into five regions (<htcite3>).
According to the work of Rebecca Doran (<htcite0>).
According to the studied sources (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

In the year <htdate0>, his father abdicated his position. Thus, Li Heng (李亨), also known by his name Suzong (肅宗) and faced the revolts, without succeeding in completely defeating them (<htcite0>).

His reign was extremely short, compared to that of his father, with both passing away in the year <htdate1>.

Reflection 3: Despite...

Despite the weakness represented by the fact that he did not fully defeat the rebels, Li Heng's (李亨) son assumed the kingdom in , and the Tang dynasty lasted until the year .


Can you imagine the reasons why the dynasty still lasted more than 145 years?

We would like to highlight one final piece of information regarding Li Heng (李亨). His relationship with Buddhism is much more prominent than that of his father, having even practiced asceticism — a practice of self-discipline and moderation, which involves certain renunciations (<htcite0>). This relationship can also be observed in his son, presented next.
According to research by Mingli Sun (<htcite0>).
According to research by Mingli Sun (<htcite0>).

In <htdate0>, Li Yu (李豫) faced the rebellion, but the country was already in ruins and the emperor's credibility was compromised, with the nation being governed by different warlords (<htcite0>).

This scenario led Li Yu (李豫), also known by his name Daizong (代宗), to become even closer to Buddhism than his predecessor, even going so far as to place more than 100 images of Buddha in his palace (<htcite1>).

Reflection 4: Chaos and famine lead to...

Climatic events caused famine, which led banditry to reach gigantic levels in the nation ().

We see that he and his father grew even closer to religious leaders in the face of problems ().

Does this attitude surprise you?

Do emperors possess the same religious understanding as you or people you know?

Have you seen people with a different religious understanding do the same?

The relationship with Buddhism did not begin with the decline of the Tang Dynasty (唐代), nor did it end with it. The reasons for centuries of relationship between empire and belief have been the subject of study by various researchers in recent years (<htcite0>).
According to the source studied (<htcite0>).
According to the researched source (<htcite0>).

Li Shi (李適), also known by his name Dezong (德宗), adopted a different attitude from that of his father. He was determined to rebuild central power, as well as to confront local forces (<htcite0>).

His measures again led the northern provinces into rebellion between <htdate0> and <htdate1>, a situation that did not worsen thanks to the alignment maintained by the southern provinces (<htcite1>).

The military system also underwent changes, with the emperor placing eunuchs in command. In addition to these changes, a new tax system was successfully implemented, making the state rich and prosperous, to the point of lasting for a few centuries, until the Ming dynasty (明代) (<htcite2>; <htcite3>).

Reflection 5: Truths more true than truth itself

Climatic events caused famine, which led banditry to gigantic levels in China (Zhongguo 中國) (). The Tang Dynasty (唐代) ended in .

In a near period, between the years and , but in Mesoamerica, climatic events such as droughts also possibly led to the end of the Classic Period and the abandonment of great Mayan cities ().

These examples show two distant regions that suffered from climatic problems that directly affected their societies, leading to collapses.

These events occurred more than 1000 years ago. However, have you ever thought that climatic problems could lead today's society to a similar collapse?

Could these problems also lead people to draw closer to beliefs as climate change causes their environment to collapse?

source.text: Hunt, B. G., & Elliott, T. I.

history.text: During the research, it was not possible to determine their name with certainty.
According to the researched source (<htcite0>).

Li Song (李婎), known after his death as Shunzong (順宗), ruled for a very short period due to an illness (<htcite0>). He showed himself to be religious, bringing Buddhist practices back into his palace (<htcite1>). Little beyond this can be stated about him.
During the research, it was not possible to determine his name with certainty.
According to the researched source (<htcite0>).

Li Chun (李純), also known by his name Xianzong (憲宗), shortly after his father's death. Among the rulers of the last century of the Tang Dynasty (唐代), he is one of the few who accomplished notable feats (<htcite0>; <htcite1>; <htcite2>).

He revoked his grandfather's measure of placing eunuchs in military command, taking command himself. At the head of his army, he re-established stability in the nation (<htcite3>; <htcite4>).

Despite his success, Li Chun (李純) also faced revolts between <htdate0> and <htdate1> (<htcite5>; <htcite6>).

His relationship with Chinese culture can be observed when, after years of chaos, he turned his attention to the imperial calligraphy collection, which, despite efforts, never returned to its former glory (<htcite7>).

Reflection 6: And education?

Should the care of calligraphy and the general knowledge of the population be the duty of any government?

At the end of his life, Li Chun (李純) became obsessed with immortality, taking various elixirs that ended up affecting his mental state. It is possible that this prevented him from observing certain events around him. The influence of the eunuchs began to become institutionalized, and one of them ended up assassinating him (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).
According to the source consulted (<htcite0>).
According to the source consulted (<htcite0>).

Li Heng (李恆), also known as Muzong (穆宗), had a brief reign. From the little that is known about him, he apparently spent his time playing polo. During one of these activities, he ended up dying as a result of an accident (<htcite0>). However, this is not the only information we have about his death. There are also publications reporting that he died after ingesting elixirs (<htcite1>). Perhaps the accident mentioned in the first publication can be explained by the second.
According to the source consulted (<htcite0>).
Person used when it was not possible to identify the emperor's mother.
According to the source consulted (<htcite0>).
According to the source consulted (<htcite0>).
According to the source consulted (<htcite0>).

Li Zhan (李湛), also known by his name Jingzong (敬宗), assumed governance at only 16 years old, committing numerous mistakes (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

Right at the beginning of his reign, in <htdate0>, he resumed the quest for immortality, which had already been undertaken by his grandfather, Li Chun (李純), Xianzong (憲宗). One of his actions with this goal was to issue several decrees searching for “uncommon men” in the south (<htcite2>).

The emperor's immaturity bothered the eunuchs, who tried to persuade his mother, Guo (郭), to take power. However, she did not accept, making a direct reference to Wu Zetian (武則天): “Are you saying that I should become another Empress Wu?” (<htcite3>).

Li Zhan (李湛) was assassinated in the year <htdate1> by his eunuchs (<htcite4>).

Reflection 7: Die for what?

Have you ever thought about being immortal? Or have you ever wished to be?

Buddhism includes reincarnation among its beliefs and was aligned with the emperors of the Tang dynasty (唐代) for a long period (). Why, even so, did the emperors not wish to die?

Are you afraid of dying? If so, why?

Law of Conservation of Matter, discovered by Antoine Lavoisier (), matter is not destroyed, not even when we die. It is always transformed. That is, the atoms of our body today were once part of something in the past (including other living beings) and may come to compose other living beings in the future.

Could there be a relationship between what we can measure (the transformation of matter) and Buddhist beliefs?

source.text: Sterner, R. W., Small, G. E. & Hood, J. M.

history.text: Li Ang (李昂), also known as Wenzong (文宗), carried out some acts which, on one hand, allowed for a certain stability in the government (<htcite0>). However, this does not mean that such actions were simple or that they had no consequences, for, as he himself concluded: “To rid Hebei of rebels is easy, to rid the court of factions is difficult!” (<htcite1>).

Reflection 8: Power

Considering that, at that time, the court was extremely linked to power, what is the effect of power on people?

Does power corrupt? Or does power reveal who people really are?

Li Ang (李昂) acted against the eunuchs, who even killed his brother (<htcite0>). However, his plans were frustrated and, in reality, ended up destabilizing the bureaucracy (<htcite1>; <htcite2>; <htcite3>). Furthermore, hostilities from the emperor towards Buddhism were observed during his reign (<htcite4>).

All of Li Ang's acts possibly had consequences for his succession. Instead of his son, Li Rong (李溶), succeeding him, the one who assumed the government was his brother, Li Chan (李瀍), with the support of the eunuch Qiu Shiliang (仇士良) (<htcite5>).
In the analyzed works, there is no detailed mention of his marriages.
According to the source studied (<htcite0>).

Li Chan (李炎), also known as Wuzong (武宗), reinstated Li Deyu (李德裕) to the position of grand councilor in <htdate0>. With the full support of the emperor, some rebellions were pacified, in addition to reducing the power of the eunuchs, mainly in the military sphere (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

Religions other than Daoism, to which the emperor belonged, once again became an imperial target. Buddhism received special persecution, possibly for economic reasons (<htcite2>; <htcite3>; <htcite4>).

Upon his death, in <htdate1>, once again the lineage was not passed to a direct heir, which is why we do not list him. Instead, his uncle, Li Cheng (李忱), assumed the government (<htcite5>).

Reflection 9: The State and religion

Again we observe divergences between the government and religions.

Should they always be separate?

Now, expanding on Reflection 8: Could religious people (not to be confused with the religion itself) also seek power through beliefs?

Li Cheng (李忱), also known as Xuanzong (宣宗), like his ancestor Li Longji (李隆基), ascended the throne carrying out positive reforms compared to those of previous emperors. He halted religious persecution, although he only allowed the reopening of Buddhist temples. Furthermore, he removed Li Deyu (李德裕) from his position as grand councilor (<htcite0>; <htcite1>; <htcite2>; <htcite3>).

He can be considered the last ruler to actually achieve something relevant; after his death, in <htdate0>, the Tang dynasty (唐代) entered its final decline (<htcite4>).

Li Cheng (李忱) died after ingesting an elixir incorrectly (<htcite5>).
During the research, it was not possible to determine their name with certainty.
According to the source consulted (<htcite0>).

Li Cui (李漼), also known as Yizong (懿宗), assumed the government in <htdate0>, maintaining an alignment with Buddhism, one of the few characteristics in which he remained aligned with his father (<htcite0>; <htcite1>; <htcite2>).

During his government, a widespread famine ravaged the country due to drought, but the government did little to help the people (<htcite3>).

Also during his government, new revolts broke out in <htdate1>, <htdate2> and <htdate3> (<htcite4>). Furthermore, the eunuchs regained relevance (<htcite5>).

source.text: Honey, D. B., & Lyon, M. P.
Honey, D. B., & Lyon, M. P.

history.text:
Li Xuan (李儇), also known by his name Xizong (懿宗), came to power at only 11 years of age, chosen by eunuchs (<htcite0>).

He assumed government having to deal with serious flooding problems that occurred shortly before his ascension. Soon after, in <htdate0>, a wave of peasant uprisings occurred (<htcite1>; <htcite2>). However, the worst was yet to come.

Huang Chao (黃巢) organized a monumental rebellion that lasted approximately a decade (<htdate1> to <htdate2>) and took control of different regions of the country. He conquered important cities, including the capture of the capital Chang'an, proclaiming himself emperor (<htcite3>; <htcite4>).

During the conquests and in his own government, Huang Chao's (黃巢) cruelty was a hallmark. According to Arab accounts from the year <htdate3>: “The inhabitants opposed him, and he left them besieged for a long period, until he defeated them. Then, he put the inhabitants to the sword. And it is mentioned that more than 120,000 Muslims, Jews, Christians, and Magians died…” (<htcite5>; <htcite6>).

This scenario of cruelty contributed to Huang Chao being removed from the capital Chang'an in <htdate4> with the help of an army still loyal and provincial generals, and he died in <htdate5>. With the help of the Shatuo Turks, the rebellion was finally defeated (<htcite7>).

Reflection 10: And here we go again...

This whole scenario leads us to one more reflection. The strongest rebellion of the Tang government did not arise from nowhere; it had roots in bad governments that taxed the people without solving their problems (). On the other hand, the rebel government also did not solve the difficulties, additionally creating great repression and maintaining the unfavorable scenario for the population.

Have you ever read or heard about governments that increase taxes while the people suffer from hunger?

Have you heard of “saviors” who overthrow these governments by force and then oppress the people?

And what about foreign intervention to assist one of the sides? Is that something new to you?

And about religion being used to appease, while religious people of different beliefs are persecuted (; ; )? Is that something new to you?

And regarding climate changes, whether due to natural or human effects? Have you heard about that?

If none of this is new, and the information you have heard is from the present day, have you ever noticed that perhaps what you are experiencing recently already happened over a thousand years ago — and that you might be seeing the same mistakes repeated?

Li Ye (李曄), also known by his temple name Zhaozong (昭宗), failed to reverse the decline of the Tang dynasty (唐代) (<htcite0>).

Apparently, little information is available about this emperor, but it can be stated that the consequences of the Huang Chao (黃巢) rebellion directly affected him. The rebel Zhu Wen (朱溫), who had followed Huang Chao (黃巢), surrendered with his troops and was rewarded with control of the Kaifeng region in central China (Zhongguo 中國). Shortly after the fall of Huang Chao (黃巢), a conflict occurred between Zhu Wen (朱溫) and the Turkish general Li Keyong, who had helped defeat the rebellion. Thanks to his victory, Zhu Wen forced Emperor Zhaozong (昭宗) to move the capital from Chang'an to Luoyang  (<htcite1>).

Li Ye (李曄) and most of his children were killed by Zhu Wen (朱溫) in the year <htdate0> (<htcite2>).
During the research, it was not possible to determine the mother's name with certainty.
According to the source studied (<htcite0>).

Li Zuo (李祚), also known by his temple name Aidi (哀帝), which means “Emperor of Sorrow” (<htcite0>), was the last emperor of the Tang dynasty (唐代).

After being the only son of Emperor Li Ye (李曄) not initially murdered by Zhu Wen (朱溫), he was elevated to the position of emperor in <htdate0>. He ruled until <htdate1>, when he was finally deposed by Zhu Wen (朱溫), who proclaimed himself emperor, thus ending the Tang dynasty (唐代) (<htcite1>). Shortly thereafter, he was murdered by Zhu Wen (朱溫) (<htcite2>).

And we come to the end of our study on the Tang dynasty (唐代). We observe many points in common with what we experience today, in the year <htdate2>, which allows us to make a final reflection. But first, observe the following **Graph 1**:
Graph 1: Linear political ideological representation.
Now, see **Graph 2**, which presents the same political ideologies, but from a different perspective (<htcite0>):
Gráfico 2: Representación ideológica política en formato de herradura.

Reflection 11: Then and now

Using Graphs 1 and 2 to analyze the Tang dynasty (唐代) is not possible, because the terms—and their definitions—were created centuries later; therefore, trying to apply conclusions before their existence would be an anachronism (). Even so, we presented them to aid in reflections between today's politicians and those of the past, as well as their attitudes towards the same problems.

When you saw the graphs before reaching this reflection, did you try to place the emperor or the rebels in any ideological position?

If so, were you aware of what an anachronism is?

Did you observe anything in common between ancient rulers—before the creation of the terms shown in the graphs—and some current rulers?

Did you observe that the revolutionaries who opposed the Tang dynasty (唐代) adopted extreme attitudes, going so far as to take the lives of others?

Before being presented with Graph 2, had it crossed your mind that extremists might be closer than they seem?

If you did not reach that conclusion, focus on Graph 1, and now answer: did you observe that extremists cease to recognize any position outside of their own extremes?

Based on the last reflections, could we conclude that, if a person claims that the problem is exclusively the right or the left, perhaps the problem lies with the person themselves, as they might have an extremist stance?

exercise_v2.question: Did the Tang Dynasty (唐代) originate among the Han Chinese?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: The Tang Dynasty (唐代) originated among the Hu peoples (胡人) — ethnic minorities who lived in northwest China (Zhongguo 中國), Central Asia, and western Eurasia.

exercise_v2.question: Was Li Shimin (李世民) a highly influential emperor throughout the Tang Dynasty?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: Due to his governance model and the advancements he promoted in Chinese society, Li Shimin (李世民) became a benchmark for future emperors. However, that was not the only reason for his influence. The fact that he chose Wu Zetian (武則天) as his concubine also influenced China's (Zhongguo 中國) future.

exercise_v2.question: After the years of Wu Zetian (武則天) as empress, did her children have problems staying in power?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo:
With the fall of the empress, Li Xian (李顯) had a brief rule, being murdered by his own wife, Princess Wei (韋). His son, Li Chongmao (李重茂), who assumed the government with the empress as regent, remained in power for a short time after a coup orchestrated by his cousin Li Longji (李隆基), his uncle Li Dan (李旦), and his aunt, Princess Taiping (太平).
Upon assuming the government, Li Dan (李旦) also remained in the position for a short time, transferring power to his son, Li Longji (李隆基), when, finally, the Chinese government returned to a period of stability.

exercise_v2.question: Was the last century of the Tang dynasty (唐代) the best of the dynasty?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: The final years of the dynasty were the most complex. The bloodlines were not followed, in addition to countless problems being recorded with eunuchs and religious figures.
